title: Charley River
listingDescription: The Charley River is a complete watershed protected within the preserve and is virtually unaltered by modern human activities.

images.altText: Aerial view of the Charley River during fall colors
images.title: Charley River Fall Colors
images.caption: Aerial view of the Charley River during fall colors

bodyText:
The Charley River is a complete watershed protected within the preserve and is virtually unaltered by modern human activities.

The preserve protects the Charley River in a free-flowing, natural state and the entire 1.1-million-acre Charley River watershed is seemingly unaffected by human activity. The Charley River basin is a focal point for scientific study of subarctic ecosystems that range from river bottoms to alpine habitat. The preserve provides habitat for populations of fish and wildlife, including but not limited to peregrine falcons and other raptorial birds, caribou, moose, Dall's sheep, grizzly bears, and wolves. Visitors are attracted to the remote and challenging floating conditions the Charley River offers, as well as opportunities for float hunting, fishing, and other recreational pursuits such as wildlife viewing.

Learn about floating the Charley River

quickFacts.value: Completely protected watershed of exceptional wild character
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Coal Creek Camp
listingDescription: A historic mining district along the Yukon River in eastern Alaska.

images.altText: The newly-assembled Coal Creek Dredge near the site of the first Coal Creek Camp buildings in 1935.
images.title: Coal Creek Camp Buildings and Dredge
images.caption: The newly-assembled Coal Creek Dredge near the site of the first Coal Creek Camp buildings in 1935.

relatedOrganizations.name: National Register of Historic Places Program

bodyText:
When the Coal Creek dredge was in operation, it traveled for miles along the creek valley, making it necessary to construct a camp for the workers built on log skids that could periodically be moved. Today the Coal Creek mining camp has been restored by the National Park Service and includes a number of bunkhouses, a mess hall, an assaying and refining office,Â machine shops, and even a public use cabin. The camp, gold dredge, and many other artifacts of the industrial gold mining era are all part of Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve.

Read more about the Coal Creek Historic Mining District.
passportStampLocationDescription: Passport Stamp may be obtained from an NPS staff member when seasonally on site in summer and fall.

passportStampImages.altText: Yukon-Charley Rivers Coal Creek Passport Stamp
passportStampImages.title: Coal Creek Passport Stamp

title: Eagle Historic District National Historic Landmark
listingDescription: A military, judicial, transportation, and communications hub for interior Alaska at the turn of the century, Fort Egbert was established as a control station and headquarters for northern Alaska in 1889.

images.altText: A two story white building with a gray roof and a two story, white, water pumping station.
images.title: Eagle Historic District, Alaska
images.caption: The courthouse at Eagle Historic District National Historic Landmark, Alaska

bodyText:
Â 

A 19th Century City in Alaska

Preserved much as it was in 1899, the small isolated community of Eagle offers visitors a rare glimpse into Alaskaâs past. In its heyday, the City of Eagle served as judicial and transportation hub for interior Alaska, and adjacent Fort Egbert as the military and communications center. Eagle began as a fur trading post around 1880. When gold was discovered at nearby American Creek, a small mining camp was established at Eagle. The rush of gold seekers to Canadaâs Klondike in brought national attention to Eagle. The prime site along the Yukon River a few miles from the Canadian border was an ideal location for the development of the City of Eagle. Fort Egbert was established as a control station and headquarters for interior Alaska in 1899 adjacent to Eagle.

Today, the Bureau of Land Management and Eagle Historical Society and Museums manage several of the historic buildings of Eagle. In addition, many of the historic homes are privately owned. A joint BLM/NPS field office is located in Eagle and can provide the visitor with more information on Eagle as well as nearby Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve.

title: Slaven's Roadhouse
listingDescription: While many historic roadhouses have burned or have rotted away, Slavenâs Roadhouse has been restored and now serves as a public use cabin and landmark along the river between Eagle and Circle. The National Park Service restored Slaven's Roadhouse to its original 1938-42 condition. Slaven's Roadhouse continues to serve the public as a landmark along the Yukon River. It is open to public access and frequently has people spending the night while traveling up and down the river.

images.title: Slaven's Roadhouse during Fall Colors
images.caption: A historic roadhouse and public use cabin on the Yukon River

relatedOrganizations.name: National Register of Historic Places Program

bodyText:
While many historic roadhouses have burned or have rotted away, Slavenâs Roadhouse has been restored and now serves as a public use cabin and landmark along the river between Eagle and Circle. From 1990 through 1996, the National Park Service restored Slaven's Roadhouse to its original 1938-42 condition.

Slaven's Roadhouse continues to serve the public as a landmark along the Yukon River. It is open to public access and frequently has people spending the night while traveling up and down the river.

Each February, it serves as a dog drop point during theÂ Yukon QuestÂ International Sled Dog Race. At times, the roadhouse also serves as quarters for volunteers working for the National Park Service.

Learn more about Slaven's Roadhouse on the Yukon-Charley Rivers website.
audioDescription: Two-story log cabin with a metal roof, set on a high bank overlooking the Yukon River.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamp is available from a Park Ranger that is often stationed at Slaven's Roadhouse during the summer and early fall.
